item.title: The assembly must be clean
item.description: Have you ever seen a list of compiler warnings the size of an essay on how not to write code and thought: “Of course, something needs to be done about this… but I just don’t have time for it right now”? And conversely, have you ever seen a single warning appear during compilation and immediately fix it? When I start a new project from scratch, there are no warnings, no mess, no problems. But as the codebase grows, if no measures are taken, it’s likely that the mess, clutter, warnings, and issues will gradually accumulate. In a large stream of “noise,” it becomes significantly harder to find a truly important warning among the hundreds of others that I am not interested in. To make warnings useful again, I try to adhere to a policy of zero tolerance for warnings during assembly.
